text: Dr. Williamson, first of all, we'd like to begin with what you're working on right now. I'm working on a novel called The Queen of the Legion. There's another story about the Legion of Space, a series that I started back in the early 30's. Is it going to be serialized like the others? Well, here's hoping. The market's sort of uncertain. Fred Pohl gave me a contract for it a couple of years ago, and I was president of the Science Fiction Writers of America going to be involved in other things and it has taken time to do, but it's finally falling together and I'm putting it into my new word processor and I'm pretty enthusiastic about it now. The main character is a girl and at first I was sort of uncertain whether I could be convincing and presenting a woman's point of view, but I've sort of fallen in love with Jill by now. I think I know her pretty well and like her, and I hope the readers do. Have you finished that trilogy with Frederick Pohl, the one on the Dyson sphere, the three volumes? No, I'm sorry to say we haven't. I finished my part of the second volume some years ago, I think. A year and a half ago, Judy Lynn Dalray gave us a revised contract with a larger advance, and her idea then was to publish all three proposed volumes in one thick volume. Fred was going to get it out last March at that time, but that's the last I've heard about it. He's promoting his work. He's involved in many projects. That's always been the history of working with him. He's a great collaborator, but he takes his time, so I have hope that he'll eventually get back to it. Recently you've been redoing some of the Humanoid material too, correct? Is there a novel that's come out? Yeah, there's a new novel called The Humanoid Touch that I finished well over a year ago, and it will be published, I think, this summer in a limited signed edition from Fantasia Press with a whole reinhardt hardcover this November. Part of that was serialized and analog. Yeah, analog reprinted or printed the middle of it under the title Humanoid Universe. There was a reference in that story or somewhere to a book called 10 trillion wise machines. What's that? Well, that was my second title, to it. First I was going to call the novel the Humanoid Universe, and Fred didn't like that and I or wanted to call it Ten Trillion Wise Machines, which is a title I like, but people wanted the name Humanoids in the title, and also that's pretty long to go on a book jacket. And J.K. Kline, a science fiction photographer, is the man who came up with the title Of Humanoid Touch, which I think is appropriate and brief and has humanoids in it, and I'm very happy with it. Perhaps you could explain the difference between humanoids and androids and robots. Well, in my mind, the robots are a mechanical man, and the humanoids are a type of robot. That is, they're made out of plastic and steel and operated by remote control by computers and so forth. Androids, as I used the term in the commentators many years ago, and is generally used as a meat machine, a synthetic or artificial human being made out of flesh and blood. The sort of thing that is possible to produce these days or in the near future by genetic engineering, let's say. That is, androids bleed and humanoids drip grease. It's interesting that you're going back and doing some of the material that you started with. Well not started with, but what you've done before—you know, the Legion material, Humanoids, and so forth. Was it 1928 you published—you began publishing? I mean, the first story was published in the November—December 1928 issue of amazing. You know, I've been a science fiction writer ever since. That was in the tradition of Merritt, wasn't it? More of a fantasy kind of? Yes, pretty much. At that time I was infatuated with Merritt. I haven't re-read him for many years lest the spell be gone, but the first stories I wrote, well, were full of these attempts at purple color, illustrated with too many adjectives, and later I began to try for more convincing settings and stronger characters and fewer adjectives. What made you start writing? Well, I grew up on a sandhill farm in the south part of this county when times were pretty grim. And I, well, wanted to be some sort of scientist without any direction or means to get a scientific education. And a few months after Gainsback started the Old Amazing, well, I came across some copies of it. and I was immediately fascinated with experiments that worked, with travel in time and spaceships to other worlds and all sorts of wonderful things, and it's been an important share of my life ever since. Did you start for the money? No, the money was, well, almost immaterial. I got $25 for that first story eventually, And after a couple of years, I earned enough writing science fiction so I didn't have to do anything else. But half the secret was that I wasn't married and was willing to live economically. So I certainly didn't do it for the money. After two years in college, I was offered a student assistantship in the chemistry lab. I could have had a different career as a chemist probably, only I was more fascinated with science fiction than I was with solid science by that time, though I have tried to keep up as best a layman can with what's going on in science. Was the account true that I read in one place where you didn't know that your story had been accepted until you saw the magazine? Yeah, that's true. I wrote these stories on an old Remington basket model typewriter in a purple ribbon and two or three of them came back. One of them was with a misspelled word in the title. And the metal man never did come back. And I was over at Canyon, Texas walking by a newsstand one day and I saw my metal man on the cover of Amazing. It was quite a thrill. What was it like to you to write for the pulp, say through the 30s and so forth? Did you feel a part of something or did you feel isolated out here? I mean there weren't many around here who could share your interest. Well the science fiction world has always been a sort of special community where we I suppose we felt we had our own special handle on science in the future and the shape of things to come. them, and though I didn't see other science fiction people very often, I read the stories and read letters in the magazines and so forth. In those days, before the paperbacks, and before TV, and before the comics, when people read a lot more for entertainment than they do nowadays, and there were really three sorts of magazines. There were the quality magazines like Harper's and the old Scribner's, Atlantic for people with brains, and the slicks printed on coated paper that would take good advertising for people with money to spend, and the pulps for people who hadn't neither brains nor money. But we had a lot of fun in the pulps, even if we were looked down upon widely. And eventually, while science fiction got recognized as being not entirely without brains, let's say. And nowadays, there's a little bit of money in it, sometimes. Back then, it wasn't called science fiction, was it? No, when I started, my first story was printed as Scientifiction. Hugo Gernsback ran the word science and fiction together. He invented the term science fiction in 29, I think. And at that time you had to explain what it was, I used to say it was adventure stories with a science background. Wasn't Gernsback, didn't he want more scientifically oriented stories? Well he preached a gospel that science fiction was sugarcoated science, that it was education, and he got a whole panel of experts with degrees that were supposed to vet the science and even in science wonder stories when he started that. But actually, I think that was as much for, well, to impress the readers as anything else. Because he did use true science in his stories when he could get it. But he also printed a lot of stories that were pretty wild. He, I think always in the magazine, the adventure element was more important than the science. I've only seen a few copies of those very early pulps. They say The Amazing Stories. That's a pretty big size. Yeah, the size that time is nowadays. Were there other sizes too or types? Well, Amazing was that size and Wonder Stories when Gernsback started that. But they were also then, they were hardly regular pulps because in the beginning they Amazing was filled up with reprints of classic science fiction. And the rates were so low that professional writers didn't write for them. So when they wrote news stories, they were mostly written by amateurs such as myself. But the pulp magazines were published in chains with, well, sometimes 20 different magazines. there were mass economies there because they could print the covers all in the same press run and so forth, and they had a standard smaller size. When Astounding came along from Clayton, first his astounding stories in super science, it was the pulp size. What was the rate, or average rate, for stories in those days? Well, Gernsback paid a half a cent a word or less, which meant, well, you'd get $25 for a short story and $0.75 for a novelette. But Clayton paid two cents a word and up, which is one reason maybe the Clayton magazines went bankrupt in the Great Depression, but that meant that I could pound out 4,000 words a day for two days and earn $160, which was a fabulous feat for a farm kid in Depression Days. That was a pretty good income back then. It was. It was a lot of money. Did you get much reader response? Did fans or readers ever...? Well, of course, I didn't know many people in the locality who read science fiction, but in those days the books of the magazines were filled up with letters and tiny type from readers, the editors and that was the principal reader response. I think the editors favored them because they didn't have to pay for the letters and they were, well, interesting to us and I used to write them myself as well as read them. It was the beginning of fandom, I suppose. For the—from what I can gather, reading back on your publishing history and so forth, — Through the 30s, you know, late 20s, early 30s, you were mostly writing, I guess I would call it space opera—the Legion material. I've never objected to space opera. I still think it's wonderful, and I even think that Star Wars could have been made out of my Legion stories as well as it was from something else. I enjoyed Star Wars tremendously as a sort of adolescent daydream. And well, the pulp readers were mostly young and as naive as I was and the space opera was a sort of symbolic escape from all sorts of things. I'm not sure how I would phrase this a change or a deepening or a more serious aspect to your fiction that begins in the late thirties, would I be right in saying that to you? Probably. I was growing up and the readers were growing up. That's something that's been going on in science fiction, at least in American science fiction all along. I think you can draw a distinction between, let's say, European or mainstream science fiction, on the one hand, which has always been recognized and treated as literature, and an American science fiction, which was looked down on. But as the readers of that grew older, some of them started writing, some of them started editing magazines, most of them outgrew science fiction, but some of them didn't. So there was a continual increase in the education, the sophistication and so forth of the whole field. Maybe you used to call it a diversification because there's still a readership for Edgar Rice Burroughs and Robert E. Howard and whatever. There are also people who, let's say, former fans who are now academic fans who are teaching science fiction courses and writing scholarly articles on science fiction to meet the publisher Paris test and so forth. So that essentially the field is just diversified into all sorts of levels and areas of interest. Did Campbell influence the way you wrote fiction at all? Well, yes. I think he influenced the way nearly everybody wrote science fiction because when he became an editor of Amazing, and later changed—I mean Astounding, and later changed the name analog. He had the best highest paying market in the field. He was, well I'd say science fiction was serious to him as a way of speculating about science and its impact and the future of mankind and so forth. He was tremendously inventive, he was full of ideas that he shared very freely, and everybody who was writing science fiction for those years, was influenced by Cammell, it seems to me, whether directly or not. If they weren't trying to write for him and reading his letters they were reading such writers as Heinlein and De Kemp and Sturgeon and a dozen others, who were Camel writers. And some people resetted Kamel and felt that it was an effort to write for him. Hanline used to complain that you couldn't sell him adult sex, but Kamel and I thought so much alike so that I always felt at home with his magazine and enjoyed working with him. and he gave me occasional, very useful suggestions that I used, and he never did edit my material heavily or try to persuade me to say anything I didn't want to say. I believe that personally he was optimistic about science and the future, but when I wrote such a pessimistic, dystopian thing as with folded hands, why he published it as it was, and asked for more. I was going to ask you about that with folded hands. You sold that one to Campbell, that was sold to him? And he suggested a sequel to it. He was fanatic for various things that look sort of crackpot nowadays, including Joseph Ryan and parapsychology. And he suggested if people's hands were folded, they would use their minds, they would develop parapsychological powers, and perhaps defeat the humanoids. I felt that the humanoids couldn't be defeated so that the ending of my novel was sort of ambiguous, but he published it as I sent it to him and the readers seemed to like it well enough. I was interested in what you wrote in the afterward to one of the recent editions of The Humanoids, the way your interpretation of it's changed. Didn't you used to see yourself, you said, as a romantic and the humanoids were bad, but then you'd alter them? Well, I think so. That is, at one level, since the humanages are machines, the perfect machine, as I originally stated the theme, the perfect machine would be perfectly dreadful because it would take away all human freedom and responsibility and opportunity for achievement. but as I came to look at the story more, it seemed to me the essential human conflict in it is the conflict between the individual and society. And the people in the stories are in a, let's say, a complex and painful emotional situation because the humanoids are meant to be good. they're presented as benign, they're trying to assure the safety and happiness of mankind, and in doing this they destroy freedom. And I decided eventually that this reflects my own very early childhood experience when people were overprotecting me because they loved me for my own good, but still I couldn't help a deep resentment because they wouldn't let me do so many things I wanted to do. And I feel, by the way, that the conflict between the individual and society is a basic material of most literature, really. You can approach it in all sorts of ways. At one level, why literature socializes us, it teaches us unselfishness and patriotism and obedience and all sorts of social virtues. and at another level why it can be critical of the influence of society on the individual, as in Ibsen especially, he presents character after character who's destroyed by the pressures of society or by conceding too much to society. In that novel, The Humanoids, And, um, Ironsmith, it seemed to me represented society or conformity and so forth. When I first read the book I kept thinking he was going to turn into an evil character, a villain, but you never made him a villain. He remained a, I don't know, a friendly person, a helpful person, but simply one who was siding with the humanoids. Has your attitude toward him changed since you got into the book? Well, I think maybe I understand him better. When I was writing the novel, I don't think I really understood him except that he was a fascinating enigma. That is, he was a likable guy. He wasn't caught up in the conflict that my main character was. He got along with the humanoids and they befriended him. And it occurred to me later that he's the example of the person who does conform to society who accepts its limitations, and as a result of that is enabled to live a more relaxed and richer life in contrast to the person always in conflict with society who in the worst instance has to destroy himself because nobody can live alone. If you were to continue with the humanoid, you know, further than you have, the humanoid stories. Would you ultimately have them, man being happy, under their care? Would they stop conquering the universe? Well, I haven't planned to to do that. In fact, I was reluctant to write any more about them till Fred Pulle offered me a contract I couldn't refuse, but in this new novel, The Humanoid Touch, where I tried to work out an alternative that doesn't involve the destruction of the humanoids but does offer an alternate way of life that is an escape from. And I don't know how readers will react, but the story, I enjoyed writing and I have hopes for it. Well, you must have, when you finished the humanoids, it was with folded hands, and say, when you finish with Folded Hands in that time period, you must have gotten some response from readers or editors that it was kind of pessimistic or dystopian because you wrote The Equalizer, didn't you, it was sort of a counter? Well, more or less, in fact. With Folded Hands, the humanoid stories were the first project that I undertook after I got home from World War II. I was an Air Force's weather forecaster in the Southwest Pacific when the bomb went off, and the atomic bomb cast a dark mushroom cloud over all science fiction. And much science fiction was suddenly pessimistic about the future, and thus this was the setting in which I wrote the humanoids. And when I started to write it, I originally felt that they could be somehow conquered or disposed of or whatever, and then as I worked with them, I realized that logically and artistically they were invincible. So I gave up in the middle of a novel I'd planned and wrote The Equalizer as an example of, let's say that technology is benevolent. It can be used to make a really better world. It he had to find man's 이야기 as kind of the world. Then I came back to the humanoid and re-plotted it and wrote with folded hands. I would just have one more question on the humanoid books—humanoid material. I guess some of the reader's—some responses I've read about it have been kind of confused or on both sides of the question as to what you meant. And my concern would be, are you optimistic about man and his future and his relation to machines? Can he control them? Can he survive them? Are they going to destroy him in his nature? Well, I think I'm optimistic. I try to be optimistic. I think that once we have technology, we can't unhave it. we can't put the genie back in the bottle. We have to accept it and live with it. I think that people who want to return to the 18th century or to the Garden of Eden or whatever are simply trying to whistle in the dark. And I think that technology can solve problems if we use it to solve problems. So I'm more optimistic than my stories. I think that to a considerable extent, a story should have its own independent theme, more or less independently of what the writer thinks or believes. When I'm trying to write a story where I like to stop after I have a reasonable start and look at it and decide what the theme is and then rearrange it if necessary to give it the strongest impact I can. Would you have any questions in this area, David? Not about the humanoids. I have one backing up a little bit. It seems that many of your stories have anticipated scientific discoveries, such as Dark Star Station anticipated neutron stars. How did you get the ideas about that? Well, it's hard to say except that I've always been fascinated with sciences—well, you can put it as a sort of mystery story of what the world is, the universe is, about its origins and development and meaning, with effort going on in a hundred fields of science to unravel the mystery, and I've always tried to read science magazines and science books and keep up with what's happening and I'm concerned with, well, what the universe is and sometimes I had speculation through my own that were later confirmed, let's say. Um, I notice a number of stories and in some of your novels, especially in the late early forties where you described totalitarian kind of societies like Breakdown. Was that the story, I think, with the Square Deal if I remember correctly, and in that area where the humans are struggling to overcome sort of a totalitarian society? Was that in any way related to the world situation? Well, I think so. At that time of course we were faced with Hitler, and a little bit later with Stalin. and I think they were too many stories at that time that placed us in a struggle with a totalitarian situation. And of course, that is sort of an ultimate statement of the problem of the society versus the individual. The individual being destroyed or at least his freedom erased by a totally arbitrary society. If I'm remembering correctly that story, Breakdown… Let's see, wasn't it the one where boss Kelen was in control? And his son wanted to go to the stars, the research—and the boss said stay on the earth, forget that. I took that as very characteristic of your fiction that you have to have a goal, a challenge, you have to keep wanting to go rather than be structured and restricted in a society. You know, kind of something to look forward to to try for. Well, I think we all need goals and promises and escapes and freedom and realization of possibility and so forth. It seems to me that, well, we are caught in this paradoxical situation between the needs of the individual and the demands of the society and we can't live completely alone we we have to have the support and love and so forth of other people but if society demands too much it's destructive so there's no final answer to it it's a matter of precarious such a set of compromises that goes on as long as we live and some people make compromises more successfully than others. I did my dissertation on H.G. Wells, who I think was a very successful compromiser with society, who lived a very rich and varied life and enjoyed the love of many gifted women and so on and so forth, in contrast with a friend of his named Gissing, George Gissing, Slumland, who, well, met society or tried to head on, and died young and bitter and poor and defeated. Yeah, didn't you sort of—if I remember one place you sort of—you didn't say this, but I got the impression Gissing was the, say, the Forester type in The Humanoids and Wells was more the Ironsmith type? Well that fits my own notion, certainly I don't know if I ever said it. Did you take Wells to be pessimistic about man's future progress? Well, I did my dissertation on Wells entitled H.G. Wells' Critic of Progress, and it seems to me that he is there saying in several ways that progress is not all we'd like it to be, that our universe is hostile or certainly not friendly to progress, and that we have a barrier in the animal nature of mankind which he explores in such things as the island of Dr Moreau and then a farther notion that progress limits itself as an evolutionary struggle and I think Wells was a Darwinian if you stop struggling you sink back so you never can reach an ultimate peak and stay there But on the other hand, Wells must have had hope for something better because he spent most of his life in a struggle to build a better society, to educate us and warn us and shape us for a world state. And he died, I think, more or less embittered and in despair. But still it seems to me that most of his life was lived in hope. I wanted to ask you a little bit too. It's fascinating to me the way science fiction caught on and began through the 30s and so forth. And oh, around 1939 if I remember people like Asimov and Heinlein, and I think it's pronounced Vanvoe— Van Voet. and vote, okay. They started publishing around that time. Were you reading these people as they started? Oh yes, they all started in Kamal's magazine. Astounding, he was—well, I don't know whether you'd say Kamal discovered them or they discovered him, But it was, let's say, a small group with a great deal of, well, fellowship or fellow understanding and so forth. And it was an exciting period in which to be alive. In 1940 I spent about a year in Los Angeles when I spent many Saturday evenings up at Bob Hanline's home. on Laurel Canyon in Hollywood when we had what we called the Manana Literary Society. It was not an organization. It was just a group of friends, but we got together and talked science fiction, and we were all reading each other's science fiction when it was published, and the field was a lot closer knit then than it is now because everybody could read all that anybody and everybody published. It was a little group and we were much closer together and, by and large, we were friends. Have you kept up, you know, personal–well, I guess as president, AFWA and so forth? SFWA, Science Fiction Writers of America? Well, I still have a lot of old friendships and make new friends, but we have upwards of 500 members in the organization, and nearly all of them have published at least a few stories, and publishers, paperback publishers, send me probably 20 or 30 free books a month, and most of these I don't have time to read. So I have old friends that I try to keep in touch with, keep up with, but it's impossible for anybody to be as intimately acquainted with all the field as we all were in the 30s and 40s. But we still have a fellowship sort of subculture that draws us together in a way that doesn't happen to readers of mystery or westerns or whatever. And it seems to me that basically it's a concern with science and technology and the impact on human beings and technology and the future that we have, well, a realization that the world is changing and a concern about what the future is going to be like, that the laymen or the mundane, as people call them, try to forget, maybe. Because if they see change at all, they're afraid of it. I read that when you were younger, you were sort of anti-nuclear power. Your position on that has changed over the years. Well, I'm certainly pro-nuclear power now. I'm not sure that I was ever strongly against it, except that when I heard that the atom had been split, I was sort of dismayed. I had known that it was possible. I'd written fiction about it as early as 1930, but I saw that it was going to make life complicated, and I wish that it hadn't happened in my time. But now since we have nuclear power it seems to me it's the safest and most necessary development that I can see. You talk about contrasting mining coal and nuclear power when you mine coal while you bring out a lot of uranium and thorium along with it when you burn it while you pollute the atmosphere with a lot more radiation than has ever escaped from a nuclear plant. You kill people in the mines and on the railways and so on and so forth so that not—nobody, to the best of my knowledge, has yet been killed in a commercial nuclear accident. And when we were developing steamboat boats on the Mississippi where we blew up people every few days and nobody thought much about it. So it seems to me we have a sort of exaggerated fear of nuclear hazards and unwillingness to open our eyes and balance the realities. And we can produce and use nuclear energy nowadays, and whatever else we do is going to be... more expensive or more dangerous or delayed or whatever. That is, space power plants, solar power or whatever offer glittering possibilities for the next century, but they can't do much for us in the next ten or twenty or thirty years. Change the subject for just a minute. How did you start to collaborate with Frederick, Paul? Well at that time Fred was my agent. and I sent him material and he suggested things that could be done with it. The first instance was something that I called the Conquest of the Abyss. I started out to write a novel about an undersea world and I pinned a bedsheet on the wall. I made maps. I did research. I described the technologies and invented people and the culture and the setup. up and when I got about halfway through what was meant to be the novel it just died. I used up all my creativity and planning it and when Fred came in, yeah, we got three undersea novels about it and our reefs of space came about more or less the same way though some what later I'd written a 400-page draft of something called the Iron Collar man that had the reefs of space and the all the essential background in it but I wasn't happy with it I never did do a final draft and when I showed it to Fred why we replieded it and he rewrote it and it's was a very successful revision speaking of anticipating science why it took a long time to get that into print I was afraid that people wouldn't start doing organ transplants too soon. But we did beat the heart transplanters, at least by a few years. Yeah, I read that you're speaking of the body bank in that one. Yes, that was a lot of fun to do and I had the body bank in my version, but Fred came up with a lot of delightfully horrifying variations and possibilities of the body bank. Did you ever run across that in fiction before to your knowledge or was that the first time people had done it? Well, so far as I knew it was near the body bank was certainly a new phrase to me. What you—I'm still curious, how—I've never understood how someone can, say collaborate on a novel. How does that work when you're in your relationship? Well, first of all a collaboration is a pretty intimate relationship, sort of like a marriage. It doesn't work unless you have a mutual trust and preferably both parties should have complementary abilities so each one can add something. I've collaborated with several people and always because I felt that they could do something I couldn't. The first collaboration was with the Dr. Miles J. Brewer. Something like 50 years ago, we wrote a novel together, as well as a short story, and a novel that I just re-read, and in some ways I thought it was pretty good, and I kind of apprenticed myself to Brewer who was selling to Amazing a couple of years ahead of me, and when you look at him now he wasn't a really brilliant writer, but he was competent and serious and took his techniques seriously, And he knew things that I wanted to learn, and I did the writing and most of the writing. And he helped with the plotting and suggested revisions and whatever. And with Fred, I, well, respect him. And first of all, I like him. And then I respect his style, his editorial sense, and his craftsmanship generally. When I'm working with someone like Fred, I think a writer needs an audience, that is, communication is a two-way process. You need to know your audience, you need feedback from your audience, and when I'm doing a first drive for someone like Fred, why, since I know him, it gives a kind of automatic focus. it helps crystallize the point of view it makes the writing go a lot faster especially since I know that he's going to do the final draft I don't have to worry about literary polish the alliterations or avoiding rhyming words or whatever write down what comes and trust him to redo it In other words, in your relationship with him, you sort of get the ideas in the first draft and he does the revision and polishing. That's basically it. In that book, that was a trilogy. You mentioned the Wreaths of Space. That was a trilogy if I recall, and the third book was Rogue Star. Right. One of the ideas that fascinated me in that book, I think it was also in the second book, Starchild, the concept of a sentient star and combining the intelligence with it with a human intelligence, that … That was an idea that appealed to me tremendously. And I'm not sure where I got it. Sturgeon wrote a story long ago called Killdozer, about a sentient thing that seized a bulldozer. And my original notion for the story was to begin with the creation of a mine that could, let's say, possess matter, could store intelligence, I think, in shifting electronic spins or whatever I had in technique. I wanted to tell the story completely from the viewpoint of the creature that was made in the laboratory and enlarged itself successively until it became the mind of a star. And I did the first draft of the story that way. But Fred didn't like it, felt that it wasn't successful, and so he had me do some more material from the viewpoints of the human characters and the stories it published had shifting points of view. And that's one collaboration that I've always a little bit regretted because I felt that the way I wanted to do it from the viewpoint of the alien could have been done and would have been something more original and difficult, though maybe harder to do. But it worked out very well as a collaboration, and evidently there was something less than successful about my first draft if Fred wouldn't have wanted to change it. Do you have any questions right now, Dan? No, I'm fascinated so far. Every once in a while I see portions of your stories, your novels that are being serialized in books like Galaxy, or Amazing, or Analog, and so forth. And there's one I've read partially, but I haven't found the rest of it. The one on Black Lantern and Snowfire. That was published as— Was that a novel? The Power of Blackness, it was three, five novelettes put together. Three of them ran in the magazine of fantasy and science fiction and I guess one in Galaxy and one in Amazing. One thing I saw, I wasn't—it seemed to me, especially as a teacher of English, I guess I look for symbolism in some places that Black Lantern seemed to me to represent, the third world, the oppressed, the Africans, the Latin Americans, a black man from the streets. Well, I think so. My original notion in the story was to write a thought—a sort of thought experiment—a set up a story situation that would be a test of primitivism versus progress. You know, the theme of primitivism is something that we as teachers of literature your delight to discover in William Faulkner or whatever. And what I did in the story was to set up the planet Nganganga, which was settled many thousand years ago by refugees from a wrecked spaceship who fell back into savagery on a hard world so that they developed a very primitive society. Meanwhile, the galactic civilization continued to evolve so that when N'Gong'a is rediscovered, we have an ultimately sophisticated technology in contrast with a more or less ultimate primitivism. Black Lantern is presented as a member of the primitive society in conflict with the other society. At that time, I was still teaching school, so I did the thing as a series of novelettes. So, it's just a way of getting it written and published. And it probably lacks unity, and I feel myself that the middle section of it is probably better than the two concluding sections. Did you mean for one of the characters in that story, I think his name was Toolsmith, did you mean for him to be the same as Ironsmith because he does speak for the computer, the machine? Well, more or less. I wonder, especially the similarity of name and the way they thought. Well, he's certainly a representative of the technological culture. Would snow fire have any, I guess I want to say symbolic value although that's not quite the word. Well, I wanted a romance, a love interest and she appealed to me as a sophisticated, a civilized person in contact with a savage on his way up and I felt there would be electricity between them. The name probably is not too successful. I thought it was sort of striking or appealing at the time but people have sneered at it. You didn't mean for black and snow, black lanterns? Well, yes, that was part of it, but it's maybe too obvious, let's say.

segments.text: Dr. Williamson, first of all, we'd like to begin with what you're working on right now.
I'm working on a novel called The Queen of the Legion.
There's another story about the Legion of Space, a series that I started back in the early 30's.
Is it going to be serialized like the others?
Well, here's hoping. The market's sort of uncertain.
Fred Pohl gave me a contract for it a couple of years ago,
and I was president of the Science Fiction Writers of America
going to be involved in other things and it has taken time to do, but it's finally falling
together and I'm putting it into my new word processor and I'm pretty enthusiastic about
it now. The main character is a girl and at first I was sort of uncertain whether I could
be convincing and presenting a woman's point of view, but I've sort of fallen in love
with Jill by now. I think I know her pretty well and like her, and I hope the readers
do.
Have you finished that trilogy with Frederick Pohl, the one on the Dyson sphere,
the three volumes?
No, I'm sorry to say we haven't.
I finished my part of the second volume some years ago, I think.
A year and a half ago, Judy Lynn Dalray gave us a revised contract with a larger advance,
and her idea then was to publish all three proposed volumes in one thick volume.
Fred was going to get it out last March at that time, but that's the last I've heard about it.
He's promoting his work. He's involved in many projects.
That's always been the history of working with him.
He's a great collaborator, but he takes his time,
so I have hope that he'll eventually get back to it.
Recently you've been redoing some of the Humanoid material too, correct?
Is there a novel that's come out?
Yeah, there's a new novel called The Humanoid Touch
that I finished well over a year ago,
and it will be published, I think, this summer
in a limited signed edition from Fantasia Press
with a whole reinhardt hardcover this November.
Part of that was serialized and analog.
Yeah, analog reprinted or printed the middle of it under the title Humanoid Universe.
There was a reference in that story or somewhere to a book called 10 trillion wise machines.
What's that?
Well, that was my second title, to it.
First I was going to call the novel the Humanoid Universe, and Fred didn't like that and I
or wanted to call it Ten Trillion Wise Machines,
which is a title I like,
but people wanted the name Humanoids in the title,
and also that's pretty long to go on a book jacket.
And J.K. Kline, a science fiction photographer,
is the man who came up with the title Of Humanoid Touch,
which I think is appropriate and brief and has humanoids in it,
and I'm very happy with it.
Perhaps you could explain the difference between humanoids and androids and robots.
Well, in my mind, the robots are a mechanical man,
and the humanoids are a type of robot.
That is, they're made out of plastic and steel
and operated by remote control by computers and so forth.
Androids, as I used the term in the commentators many years ago,
and is generally used as a meat machine,
a synthetic or artificial human being made out of flesh and blood.
The sort of thing that is possible to produce these days
or in the near future by genetic engineering, let's say.
That is, androids bleed and humanoids drip grease.
It's interesting that you're going back
and doing some of the material that you started with.
Well not started with, but what you've done before—you know, the Legion material,
Humanoids, and so forth.
Was it 1928 you published—you began publishing?
I mean, the first story was published in the November—December 1928 issue of amazing.
You know, I've been a science fiction writer ever since.
That was in the tradition of Merritt, wasn't it?
More of a fantasy kind of?
Yes, pretty much.
At that time I was infatuated with Merritt.
I haven't re-read him for many years lest the spell be gone,
but the first stories I wrote, well, were full of these attempts
at purple color, illustrated with too many adjectives,
and later I began to try for more convincing settings
and stronger characters and fewer adjectives.
What made you start writing?
Well, I grew up on a sandhill farm in the south part of this county
when times were pretty grim.
And I, well, wanted to be some sort of scientist
without any direction or means to get a scientific education.
And a few months after Gainsback started the Old Amazing,
well, I came across some copies of it.
and I was immediately fascinated with experiments that worked,
with travel in time and spaceships to other worlds
and all sorts of wonderful things,
and it's been an important share of my life ever since.
Did you start for the money?
No, the money was, well, almost immaterial.
I got $25 for that first story eventually,
And after a couple of years, I earned enough writing science fiction
so I didn't have to do anything else.
But half the secret was that I wasn't married and was willing to live economically.
So I certainly didn't do it for the money.
After two years in college, I was offered a student assistantship in the chemistry lab.
I could have had a different career as a chemist probably, only I was more fascinated with
science fiction than I was with solid science by that time, though I have tried to keep
up as best a layman can with what's going on in science.
Was the account true that I read in one place where you didn't know that
your story had been accepted until you saw the magazine?
Yeah, that's true.
I wrote these stories on an old Remington basket model typewriter in a purple ribbon
and two or three of them came back.
One of them was with a misspelled word in the title.
And the metal man never did come back.
And I was over at Canyon, Texas walking by a newsstand one day
and I saw my metal man on the cover of Amazing.
It was quite a thrill.
What was it like to you to write for the pulp, say through the 30s and so forth?
Did you feel a part of something or did you feel isolated out here?
I mean there weren't many around here who could share your interest.
Well the science fiction world has always been a sort of special community where we
I suppose we felt we had our own special handle on science in the future and the shape of
things to come.
them, and though I didn't see other science fiction people very often, I read the stories
and read letters in the magazines and so forth. In those days, before the paperbacks,
and before TV, and before the comics, when people read a lot more for entertainment than
they do nowadays, and there were really three sorts of magazines.
There were the quality magazines like Harper's
and the old Scribner's, Atlantic for people with brains,
and the slicks printed on coated paper
that would take good advertising for people with money to spend,
and the pulps for people who hadn't neither brains nor money.
But we had a lot of fun in the pulps,
even if we were looked down upon widely.
And eventually, while science fiction got recognized
as being not entirely without brains, let's say.
And nowadays, there's a little bit of money in it, sometimes.
Back then, it wasn't called science fiction, was it?
No, when I started, my first story was printed as Scientifiction.
Hugo Gernsback ran the word science and fiction together.
He invented the term science fiction in 29, I think.
And at that time you had to explain what it was, I used to say it was adventure stories
with a science background.
Wasn't Gernsback, didn't he want more scientifically oriented stories?
Well he preached a gospel that science fiction was sugarcoated science, that it was education,
and he got a whole panel of experts with degrees that were supposed to vet the science and
even in science wonder stories when he started that.
But actually, I think that was as much for,
well, to impress the readers as anything else.
Because he did use true science
in his stories when he could get it.
But he also printed a lot of stories that were pretty wild.
He, I think always in the magazine,
the adventure element was more important than the science.
I've only seen a few copies of those very early pulps.
They say The Amazing Stories.
That's a pretty big size.
Yeah, the size that time is nowadays.
Were there other sizes too or types?
Well, Amazing was that size and Wonder Stories when Gernsback started that.
But they were also then, they were hardly regular pulps because in the beginning they
Amazing was filled up with reprints of classic science fiction.
And the rates were so low that professional writers didn't write for them.
So when they wrote news stories, they were mostly written by amateurs such as myself.
But the pulp magazines were published in chains with, well, sometimes 20 different magazines.
there were mass economies there because they could print the covers all in the same press
run and so forth, and they had a standard smaller size.
When Astounding came along from Clayton, first his astounding stories in super
science, it was the pulp size.
What was the rate, or average rate, for stories in those days?
Well, Gernsback paid a half a cent a word or less,
which meant, well, you'd get $25 for a short story
and $0.75 for a novelette.
But Clayton paid two cents a word and up,
which is one reason maybe the Clayton magazines
went bankrupt in the Great Depression,
but that meant that I could pound out
4,000 words a day for two days
and earn $160, which was a fabulous feat for a farm kid in Depression Days.
That was a pretty good income back then.
It was. It was a lot of money.
Did you get much reader response? Did fans or readers ever...?
Well, of course, I didn't know many people in the locality who read science fiction,
but in those days the books of the magazines were filled up with letters and tiny type from readers,
the editors and that was the principal reader response.
I think the editors favored them because they didn't have to pay for the letters and they
were, well, interesting to us and I used to write them myself as well as read them.
It was the beginning of fandom, I suppose.
For the—from what I can gather, reading back on your publishing history and so forth,
— Through the 30s, you know, late 20s, early 30s, you were mostly writing, I guess I would
call it space opera—the Legion material.
I've never objected to space opera.
I still think it's wonderful, and I even think that Star Wars could have been made
out of my Legion stories as well as it was from something else.
I enjoyed Star Wars tremendously as a sort of adolescent daydream.
And well, the pulp readers were mostly young and as naive as I was and the space opera
was a sort of symbolic escape from all sorts of things.
I'm not sure how I would phrase this a change or a deepening or a more serious
aspect to your fiction that begins in the late thirties, would I be right in saying
that to you?
Probably. I was growing up and the readers were growing up.
That's something that's been going on in science fiction, at least in American science fiction all along.
I think you can draw a distinction between, let's say, European or mainstream science fiction,
on the one hand, which has always been recognized and treated as literature,
and an American science fiction, which was looked down on.
But as the readers of that grew older, some of them started writing, some of them started editing magazines,
most of them outgrew science fiction, but some of them didn't.
So there was a continual increase in the education, the sophistication and so forth of the whole field.
Maybe you used to call it a diversification because there's still a readership for Edgar Rice Burroughs
and Robert E. Howard and whatever.
There are also people who, let's say,
former fans who are now academic fans
who are teaching science fiction courses
and writing scholarly articles on science fiction
to meet the publisher Paris test and so forth.
So that essentially the field is just diversified
into all sorts of levels and areas of interest.
Did Campbell influence the way you wrote fiction at all?
Well, yes.
I think he influenced the way nearly everybody wrote science fiction because when he became
an editor of Amazing, and later changed—I mean Astounding, and later changed the name
analog. He had the best highest paying market in the field. He was, well I'd say
science fiction was serious to him as a way of speculating about science and its
impact and the future of mankind and so forth. He was tremendously inventive, he
was full of ideas that he shared very freely, and everybody who was writing
science fiction for those years, was influenced by Cammell, it seems to me, whether directly
or not.
If they weren't trying to write for him and reading his letters they were reading such
writers as Heinlein and De Kemp and Sturgeon and a dozen others, who were Camel writers.
And some people resetted Kamel and felt that it was an effort to write for him.
Hanline used to complain that you couldn't sell him adult sex,
but Kamel and I thought so much alike so that I always felt at home with his magazine
and enjoyed working with him.
and he gave me occasional, very useful suggestions that I used,
and he never did edit my material heavily
or try to persuade me to say anything I didn't want to say.
I believe that personally he was optimistic about science and the future,
but when I wrote such a pessimistic, dystopian thing as with folded hands,
why he published it as it was, and asked for more.
I was going to ask you about that with folded hands.
You sold that one to Campbell, that was sold to him?
And he suggested a sequel to it.
He was fanatic for various things that look sort of crackpot nowadays,
including Joseph Ryan and parapsychology.
And he suggested if people's hands were folded, they would use their minds,
they would develop parapsychological powers,
and perhaps defeat the humanoids.
I felt that the humanoids couldn't be defeated
so that the ending of my novel was sort of ambiguous,
but he published it as I sent it to him
and the readers seemed to like it well enough.
I was interested in what you wrote in the afterward
to one of the recent editions of The Humanoids,
the way your interpretation of it's changed.
Didn't you used to see yourself, you said, as a romantic
and the humanoids were bad, but then you'd alter them?
Well, I think so. That is, at one level, since the humanages are machines, the perfect
machine, as I originally stated the theme, the perfect machine would be perfectly dreadful
because it would take away all human freedom and responsibility and opportunity for achievement.
but as I came to look at the story more,
it seemed to me the essential human conflict in it
is the conflict between the individual and society.
And the people in the stories are in a,
let's say, a complex and painful emotional situation
because the humanoids are meant to be good.
they're presented as benign, they're trying to assure the safety and happiness of mankind,
and in doing this they destroy freedom.
And I decided eventually that this reflects my own very early childhood experience
when people were overprotecting me because they loved me for my own good,
but still I couldn't help a deep resentment
because they wouldn't let me do so many things I wanted to do.
And I feel, by the way, that the conflict between the individual and society is a basic material of most literature, really.
You can approach it in all sorts of ways.
At one level, why literature socializes us, it teaches us unselfishness and patriotism and obedience and all sorts of social virtues.
and at another level why it can be critical of the influence of society on the individual,
as in Ibsen especially, he presents character after character
who's destroyed by the pressures of society or by conceding too much to society.
In that novel, The Humanoids,
And, um, Ironsmith, it seemed to me represented society or conformity and so forth.
When I first read the book I kept thinking he was going to turn into an evil character,
a villain, but you never made him a villain.
He remained a, I don't know, a friendly person, a helpful person, but simply one who was siding
with the humanoids.
Has your attitude toward him changed since you got into the book?
Well, I think maybe I understand him better.
When I was writing the novel, I don't think I really understood him
except that he was a fascinating enigma.
That is, he was a likable guy.
He wasn't caught up in the conflict that my main character was.
He got along with the humanoids and they befriended him.
And it occurred to me later that he's the example of the person
who does conform to society who accepts its limitations, and as a result of that is
enabled to live a more relaxed and richer life in contrast to the person always in conflict
with society who in the worst instance has to destroy himself because nobody can live
alone.
If you were to continue with the humanoid, you know, further than you have, the humanoid
stories.
Would you ultimately have them, man being happy, under their care?
Would they stop conquering the universe?
Well, I haven't planned to to do that.
In fact, I was reluctant to write any more about them till Fred Pulle offered me a contract
I couldn't refuse, but in this new novel, The Humanoid Touch, where I tried to work
out an alternative that doesn't involve the destruction of the humanoids but does offer
an alternate way of life that is an escape from. And I don't know how readers will react,
but the story, I enjoyed writing and I have hopes for it.
Well, you must have, when you finished the humanoids, it was with folded hands,
and say, when you finish with Folded Hands in that time period,
you must have gotten some response from readers or editors
that it was kind of pessimistic or dystopian
because you wrote The Equalizer, didn't you,
it was sort of a counter?
Well, more or less, in fact.
With Folded Hands, the humanoid stories
were the first project that I undertook
after I got home from World War II.
I was an Air Force's weather forecaster
in the Southwest Pacific when the bomb went off,
and the atomic bomb cast a dark mushroom cloud
over all science fiction.
And much science fiction was suddenly pessimistic
about the future,
and thus this was the setting in which I wrote the humanoids.
And when I started to write it,
I originally felt that they could be somehow conquered
or disposed of or whatever,
and then as I worked with them,
I realized that logically and artistically they were invincible.
So I gave up in the middle of a novel I'd planned
and wrote The Equalizer as an example of,
let's say that technology is benevolent.
It can be used to make a really better world.
It he had to find man's 이야기 as kind of the world.
Then I came back to the humanoid and re-plotted it and wrote with folded hands.
I would just have one more question on the humanoid books—humanoid material.
I guess some of the reader's—some responses I've read about it have been kind of confused
or on both sides of the question as to what you meant.
And my concern would be, are you optimistic about man and his future and his relation to machines?
Can he control them? Can he survive them? Are they going to destroy him in his nature?
Well, I think I'm optimistic. I try to be optimistic.
I think that once we have technology, we can't unhave it.
we can't put the genie back in the bottle.
We have to accept it and live with it.
I think that people who want to return to the 18th century
or to the Garden of Eden or whatever
are simply trying to whistle in the dark.
And I think that technology can solve problems
if we use it to solve problems.
So I'm more optimistic than my stories.
I think that to a considerable extent, a story should have its own independent theme, more
or less independently of what the writer thinks or believes.
When I'm trying to write a story where I like to stop after I have a reasonable start
and look at it and decide what the theme is and then rearrange it if necessary to give
it the strongest impact I can.
Would you have any questions in this area, David?
Not about the humanoids.
I have one backing up a little bit.
It seems that many of your stories have anticipated scientific discoveries, such as
Dark Star Station anticipated neutron stars.
How did you get the ideas about that?
Well, it's hard to say except that I've always been fascinated with sciences—well,
you can put it as a sort of mystery story of what the world is, the universe is, about
its origins and development and meaning, with effort going on in a hundred fields of science
to unravel the mystery, and I've always tried to read science magazines and science
books and keep up with what's happening and I'm concerned with, well, what the universe
is and sometimes I had speculation through my own that were later confirmed, let's
say.
Um, I notice a number of stories and in some of your novels, especially in the late
early forties where you described totalitarian kind of societies like Breakdown.
Was that the story, I think, with the Square Deal if I remember correctly, and in that
area where the humans are struggling to overcome sort of a totalitarian society?
Was that in any way related to the world situation?
Well, I think so.
At that time of course we were faced with Hitler, and a little bit later with Stalin.
and I think they were too many stories at that time
that placed us in a struggle with a totalitarian situation.
And of course, that is sort of an ultimate statement
of the problem of the society versus the individual.
The individual being destroyed or at least his freedom erased
by a totally arbitrary society.
If I'm remembering correctly that story, Breakdown…
Let's see, wasn't it the one where boss Kelen was in control?
And his son wanted to go to the stars, the research—and the boss said stay
on the earth, forget that.
I took that as very characteristic of your fiction that you have to have a goal, a challenge,
you have to keep wanting to go rather than be structured and restricted in a society.
You know, kind of something to look forward to to try for.
Well, I think we all need goals and promises and escapes and freedom and realization
of possibility and so forth.
It seems to me that, well, we are caught in this paradoxical situation between the needs
of the individual and the demands of the society and we can't live completely
alone we we have to have the support and love and so forth of other people but
if society demands too much it's destructive so there's no final answer
to it it's a matter of precarious such a set of compromises that goes on as long
as we live and some people make compromises more successfully than
others. I did my dissertation on H.G. Wells, who I think was a very successful compromiser
with society, who lived a very rich and varied life and enjoyed the love of many gifted women
and so on and so forth, in contrast with a friend of his named Gissing, George Gissing,
Slumland, who, well, met society or tried to head on, and died young and bitter and
poor and defeated.
Yeah, didn't you sort of—if I remember one place you sort of—you didn't say
this, but I got the impression Gissing was the, say, the Forester type in The Humanoids
and Wells was more the Ironsmith type?
Well that fits my own notion, certainly I don't know if I ever said it.
Did you take Wells to be pessimistic about man's future progress?
Well, I did my dissertation on Wells entitled H.G. Wells' Critic of Progress,
and it seems to me that he is there saying in several ways that progress is not all we'd like it to be,
that our universe is hostile or certainly not friendly to progress,
and that we have a barrier
in the animal nature of mankind
which he explores in such things
as the island of Dr Moreau
and then a farther notion
that progress limits itself
as an evolutionary struggle
and I think Wells was a Darwinian
if you stop struggling you sink back
so you never can reach an ultimate peak
and stay there
But on the other hand, Wells must have had hope for something better because he spent
most of his life in a struggle to build a better society, to educate us and warn us
and shape us for a world state.
And he died, I think, more or less embittered and in despair.
But still it seems to me that most of his life was lived in hope.
I wanted to ask you a little bit too.
It's fascinating to me the way science fiction caught on and began through the 30s and so
forth.
And oh, around 1939 if I remember people like Asimov and Heinlein, and I think it's
pronounced Vanvoe—
Van Voet.
and vote, okay. They started publishing around that time. Were you reading these people as they started?
Oh yes, they all started in Kamal's magazine. Astounding, he was—well, I don't know whether you'd say Kamal discovered them or they discovered him,
But it was, let's say, a small group with a great deal of, well, fellowship or fellow understanding and so forth.
And it was an exciting period in which to be alive.
In 1940 I spent about a year in Los Angeles when I spent many Saturday evenings up at Bob Hanline's home.
on Laurel Canyon in Hollywood when we had what we called the Manana Literary Society.
It was not an organization. It was just a group of friends, but we got together and talked science
fiction, and we were all reading each other's science fiction when it was published, and
the field was a lot closer knit then than it is now because everybody could read all that anybody
and everybody published. It was a little group and we were much closer together and, by and
large, we were friends.
Have you kept up, you know, personal–well, I guess as president, AFWA and so forth?
SFWA, Science Fiction Writers of America? Well, I still have a lot of old friendships
and make new friends,
but we have upwards of 500 members in the organization,
and nearly all of them have published at least a few stories,
and publishers, paperback publishers,
send me probably 20 or 30 free books a month,
and most of these I don't have time to read.
So I have old friends that I try to keep in touch with, keep up with,
but it's impossible for anybody to be as intimately acquainted with all the field
as we all were in the 30s and 40s.
But we still have a fellowship sort of subculture
that draws us together in a way that doesn't happen
to readers of mystery or westerns or whatever.
And it seems to me that basically it's a concern
with science and technology and the impact
on human beings and technology and the future
that we have, well, a realization that the world is changing
and a concern about what the future is
going to be like, that the laymen or the mundane, as people call them, try to forget, maybe.
Because if they see change at all, they're afraid of it.
I read that when you were younger, you were sort of anti-nuclear power.
Your position on that has changed over the years.
Well, I'm certainly pro-nuclear power now.
I'm not sure that I was ever strongly against it,
except that when I heard that the atom had been split,
I was sort of dismayed.
I had known that it was possible.
I'd written fiction about it as early as 1930,
but I saw that it was going to make life complicated,
and I wish that it hadn't happened in my time.
But now since we have nuclear power
it seems to me it's the safest
and most necessary development that I can see.
You talk about contrasting mining coal and nuclear power
when you mine coal
while you bring out a lot of uranium and thorium along with it
when you burn it
while you pollute the atmosphere with a lot more radiation
than has ever escaped from a nuclear plant.
You kill people in the mines and on the railways and so on and so forth so that not—nobody,
to the best of my knowledge, has yet been killed in a commercial nuclear accident.
And when we were developing steamboat boats on the Mississippi where we blew up people
every few days and nobody thought much about it.
So it seems to me we have a sort of exaggerated fear of nuclear hazards
and unwillingness to open our eyes and balance the realities.
And we can produce and use nuclear energy nowadays,
and whatever else we do is going to be...
more expensive or more dangerous or delayed or whatever.
That is, space power plants, solar power or whatever offer glittering possibilities for
the next century, but they can't do much for us in the next ten or twenty or thirty
years.
Change the subject for just a minute.
How did you start to collaborate with Frederick, Paul?
Well at that time Fred was my agent.
and I sent him material and he suggested things that could be done with it.
The first instance was something that I called the Conquest of the Abyss.
I started out to write a novel about an undersea world
and I pinned a bedsheet on the wall.
I made maps.
I did research.
I described the technologies and invented people and the culture and the setup.
up and when I got about halfway through what was meant to be the novel it just died. I
used up all my creativity and planning it and when Fred came in, yeah, we got three
undersea novels about it and our reefs of space came about more or less the same way
though some what later I'd written a 400-page draft of something called the Iron Collar
man that had the reefs of space and the all the essential background in it but
I wasn't happy with it I never did do a final draft and when I showed it to Fred
why we replieded it and he rewrote it and it's was a very successful revision
speaking of anticipating science why it took a long time to get that into print
I was afraid that people wouldn't start doing organ transplants too soon.
But we did beat the heart transplanters, at least by a few years.
Yeah, I read that you're speaking of the body bank in that one.
Yes, that was a lot of fun to do and I had the body bank in my version, but Fred came
up with a lot of delightfully horrifying variations and possibilities of the body bank.
Did you ever run across that in fiction before to your knowledge or was that the first time
people had done it?
Well, so far as I knew it was near the body bank was certainly a new phrase to me.
What you—I'm still curious, how—I've never understood how someone can, say collaborate
on a novel.
How does that work when you're in your relationship?
Well, first of all a collaboration is a pretty intimate relationship, sort of like
a marriage. It doesn't work unless you have a mutual trust and preferably both parties
should have complementary abilities so each one can add something. I've collaborated with
several people and always because I felt that they could do something I couldn't. The first
collaboration was with the Dr. Miles J. Brewer. Something like 50 years ago, we wrote a novel
together, as well as a short story, and a novel that I just re-read, and in some ways
I thought it was pretty good, and I kind of apprenticed myself to Brewer who was selling
to Amazing a couple of years ahead of me, and when you look at him now he wasn't a
really brilliant writer, but he was competent and serious and took his techniques seriously,
And he knew things that I wanted to learn, and I did the writing and most of the writing.
And he helped with the plotting and suggested revisions and whatever.
And with Fred, I, well, respect him.
And first of all, I like him.
And then I respect his style, his editorial sense, and his craftsmanship generally.
When I'm working with someone like Fred, I think a writer needs an audience, that is,
communication is a two-way process.
You need to know your audience, you need feedback from your audience, and when I'm doing a
first drive for someone like Fred, why, since I know him, it gives a kind of automatic focus.
it helps
crystallize the point of view
it makes the writing
go a lot faster
especially since I know
that he's going to do the final
draft I don't have to worry about
literary polish
the alliterations
or avoiding rhyming words
or whatever
write down what comes
and trust him
to redo it
In other words, in your relationship with him, you sort of get the ideas in the first
draft and he does the revision and polishing.
That's basically it.
In that book, that was a trilogy.
You mentioned the Wreaths of Space.
That was a trilogy if I recall, and the third book was Rogue Star.
Right.
One of the ideas that fascinated me in that book, I think it was also in the second book,
Starchild, the concept of a sentient star and combining the intelligence with it with
a human intelligence, that … That was an idea that appealed to me tremendously.
And I'm not sure where I got it.
Sturgeon wrote a story long ago called Killdozer, about a sentient thing that seized a bulldozer.
And my original notion for the story was to begin with the creation of a mine that could,
let's say, possess matter,
could store intelligence, I think,
in shifting electronic spins or whatever I had in technique.
I wanted to tell the story completely
from the viewpoint of the creature
that was made in the laboratory
and enlarged itself successively
until it became the mind of a star.
And I did the first draft of the story that way.
But Fred didn't like it, felt that it wasn't successful, and so he had me do some more
material from the viewpoints of the human characters and the stories it published had
shifting points of view.
And that's one collaboration that I've always a little bit regretted because I felt
that the way I wanted to do it from the viewpoint of the alien could have been done and would
have been something more original and difficult, though maybe harder to do. But it worked out
very well as a collaboration, and evidently there was something less than successful about
my first draft if Fred wouldn't have wanted to change it.
Do you have any questions right now, Dan?
No, I'm fascinated so far.
Every once in a while I see portions of your stories, your novels that are being serialized
in books like Galaxy, or Amazing, or Analog, and so forth.
And there's one I've read partially, but I haven't found the rest of it.
The one on Black Lantern and Snowfire.
That was published as—
Was that a novel?
The Power of Blackness, it was three, five novelettes put together.
Three of them ran in the magazine of fantasy and science fiction and I guess one in Galaxy
and one in Amazing.
One thing I saw, I wasn't—it seemed to me, especially as a teacher of English,
I guess I look for symbolism in some places that Black Lantern seemed to me to represent,
the third world, the oppressed, the Africans, the Latin Americans, a black man from the
streets.
Well, I think so. My original notion in the story was to write a thought—a sort
of thought experiment—a set up a story situation that would be a test of primitivism versus
progress. You know, the theme of primitivism is something that we as teachers of literature
your delight to discover in William Faulkner or whatever.
And what I did in the story was to set up the planet Nganganga,
which was settled many thousand years ago by refugees from a wrecked spaceship
who fell back into savagery on a hard world
so that they developed a very primitive society.
Meanwhile, the galactic civilization continued to evolve
so that when N'Gong'a is rediscovered,
we have an ultimately sophisticated technology
in contrast with a more or less ultimate primitivism.
Black Lantern is presented as a member of the primitive society
in conflict with the other society.
At that time, I was still teaching school,
so I did the thing as a series of novelettes.
So, it's just a way of getting it written and published.
And it probably lacks unity,
and I feel myself that the middle section of it
is probably better than the two concluding sections.
Did you mean for one of the characters in that story,
I think his name was Toolsmith,
did you mean for him to be the same as Ironsmith
because he does speak for the computer, the machine?
Well, more or less.
I wonder, especially the similarity of name and the way they thought.
Well, he's certainly a representative of the technological culture.
Would snow fire have any, I guess I want to say symbolic value although that's not
quite the word.
Well, I wanted a romance, a love interest and she appealed to me as a sophisticated,
a civilized person in contact with a savage on his way up and I felt there would be electricity
between them.
The name probably is not too successful.
I thought it was sort of striking or appealing at the time but people have sneered at it.
You didn't mean for black and snow, black lanterns?
Well, yes, that was part of it, but it's maybe too obvious, let's say.
